questions.text: Which drug was blamed to be "the cause of more fatal casualties among the servicemen at Pearl Harbour than the enemy bombs"?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Thiopentone sodium was blamed for "causing more fatal casualties among the servicemen at Pearl Harbour than the enemy bombs" due to its potent CNS and respiratory depressant effects, which led to numerous deaths when used without adequate monitoring or resuscitation equipment during World War II.

Mechanism of Action:

Thiopentone (also called thiopental) is a barbiturate that acts as a positive allosteric modulator of the GABA-A receptor.

  • It enhances the effect of GABA, increasing chloride ion influx into neurons, leading to hyperpolarization and CNS depression.
  • It causes rapid induction of anesthesia (within seconds), making it effective for short procedures or induction prior to other agents.

Side Effects:

  • Profound respiratory depression
  • Severe hypotension, especially in hypovolemic or shocked patients
  • Laryngospasm, apnea
  • Narrow therapeutic window, leading to overdose risk in field conditions

Why It Caused More Casualties:

  • During WWII, particularly in field hospitals like at Pearl Harbour, resuscitative equipment (manual ventilation, oxygen) was not available.
  • Thiopentone’s fast onset but dangerous hemodynamic effects led to deaths from apnea and cardiovascular collapse, especially in patients already compromised from trauma or shock.
  • In poorly monitored settings, small dosing errors could be fatal, as the drug accumulates in fat and is not easily reversed.

Advantages Over Older Barbiturates:

  • Unlike hexobarbital or pentobarbital, thiopentone had:
    • Rapid onset of action
    • Shorter duration
    • Smoother induction without excitatory movements
    • Reduced postoperative agitation or excitement

These benefits made it preferred for induction of anesthesia until safer alternatives (e.g., propofol) became available.

Explanation of other options:

Methohexital (Option A): It is an oxybarbiturate introduced in the 1950s, not available in WWII.

Ketamine (Option B): It was discovered in the early 1960s; used clinically in the 1970s.

Propofol (Option C): It was first synthesised in 1977 and entered clinical practice in the 1980s.

questions.text: What is the contribution of the following scientist to anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The scientist in question is Humphry Davy.
  • While he did not discover nitrous oxide (that credit goes to Joseph Priestley), he was the first to systematically study its physiological effects and noted its analgesic properties.
  • In 1800, after self-experimentation during a period of dental pain, he proposed its potential use during surgical operations - thus laying the groundwork for its future use in anaesthesia.

questions.text: The first application of cocaine for local anaesthesia was done as a topical anaesthetic for ophthalmological surgeries. This was done by which scientist?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The correct answer is Karl Koller.
  • In 1884, Karl Koller, an ophthalmology resident in Vienna, became the first to demonstrate the topical anaesthetic effect of cocaine on the eye. Under the guidance of Ernst Fuchs, he applied cocaine eye drops, resulting in complete corneal anaesthesia - a groundbreaking advancement for ophthalmic surgery. This marked the first surgical use of a local anaesthetic.

Explanation for answer:

John Lundy of the Mayo Clinic introduced the concept of "balanced anaesthesia" in 1926. This approach aimed to improve anaesthetic safety and effectiveness by combining multiple agents, each targeting a different component of anaesthesia:

  • Thiopental for induction
  • Nitrous oxide for amnesia
  • Opioids for analgesia
  • Curare for muscle relaxation

The goal was to minimize the side effects of each individual drug by using smaller doses in combination, thereby achieving a more controlled and balanced anaesthetic state.

Explanation of other options:

Oliver Holmes (Option A): Coined the term "anaesthesia" (1846)

John Snow (Option B): Pioneering work in obstetric anaesthesia (chloroform to Queen Victoria, 1853) and epidemiology.

WTG Morton (Option C): Performed the first public demonstration of ether anaesthesia (1846)

questions.text: "Chloroform a la reine", a technique was invented by ?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Chloroform à la reine technique was invented by John Snow.
  • During Queen Victoria's eighth childbirth in 1853, Snow delivered measured chloroform doses via a folded handkerchief, achieving effective analgesia.
  • Victoria abhorred the pain of labour and enjoyed the relief that chloroform provided; she wrote in her journal," Snow gave that blessed chloroform and the effect was soothing, quieting, and delightful beyond measure".Royal endorsement by Queen Victoria accelerated public and medical acceptance of obstetric anaesthesia.
  • Snow’s technique set the pattern for later calibrated vaporisers and safer inhalational anaesthesia delivery.

Explanation of other options:

  • James Young Simpson (Option A) popularised chloroform use in obstetrics but did not invent this technique.
  • Joseph Clover (Option C) innovated the chloroform delivery apparatus in 1862, succeeding Snow's methods.
  • Joseph Lister (Option D): Pioneer of antisepsis, not associated with this chloroform technique.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9373204/?

questions.text: The Laryngeal mask airway was discovered by
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In 1981, British anaesthesiologist Archie Brain developed the prototype of the laryngeal mask airway at London Hospital, Whitechapel
  • His design provided a reliable seal over the laryngeal inlet, combining ease of use with minimal airway trauma.
  • The LMA was patented in 1982 and commercially introduced in 1988, revolutionising airway management.
  • Brain demonstrated the first commercially made silicone model of LMA.

Explanation of other options:

John Snow (Option A): Pioneer of chloroform anaesthesia, not airway devices.

Melzack and Wall (Option B): Pain researchers known for the gate control theory, unrelated.

Joseph Thomas Clover (Option D): Developed early chloroform and ether inhalers, not the LMA.
